Gregory



  THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Supreme Court
  
  
    
      
        
  The State, Respondent,
  v.
  Harold Gregory, Appellant.
        
      
    
  
  
  Appeal From Aiken County
  Â James R. Barber, Circuit Court Judge
  
  Opinion No. 25972
  Heard March 3, 2005 - Filed April 18, 2005
  
  REVERSED AND
  REMANDED
  
  
    
      
        
  William Joseph Sussman, of Augusta, for Appellant.
  Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., all of Columbia, and Solicitor Barbara R. Morgan, of Aiken, for Respondent.
        
      
    
  
  
   JUSTICE WALLER: This case was certified to this Court from the Court of Appeals pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR.Â  Appellant, Harold Gregory, was convicted of two counts of committing a lewd act on a child and sentenced to concurrent twelve year terms of imprisonment.Â  We reverse.
  FACTS
  Gregory was indicted for two counts of criminal sexual conduct with a minor in the second degree, two counts of committing a lewd act on a child, and one count of first-degree sexual exploitation of a minor.Â  The acts allegedly committed by Gregory all involved his adopted daughter, Melissa.Â  
  Melissa was born on June 23, 1973.Â  Gregory married her mother when she was 5 years old.Â  According to Melissaâ€™s testimony at trial, when she was approximately 10 years old, Gregory began coming into her bedroom at night and molesting her.Â  The molestation continued until she was approximately 13 years old, at which time Gregory adopted her, and ceased molesting her for a period of time.Â  He began the molestation again which went on, off and on, until she was 28 years old.Â  Gregoryâ€™s defense at trial was that, although he and Melissa had engaged in inappropriate acts, they had all happened after she had turned 18.Â  
  The jury convicted Gregory of two counts of lewd act upon a child.Â  
  ISSUE
  Although numerous issues are raised, the sole issue we need address is whether the trial court erred in refusing to grant a continuance and relieve Gregoryâ€™s attorney due to the attorneyâ€™s conflict of interest?
  DISCUSSION
  On the first day of trial, Gregoryâ€™s defense attorney moved to be relieved as counsel and requested a continuance.Â  He advised the court that he had begun representing Gregory in June 2002 and that, in January 2003, he began representing an Aiken County Assistant Solicitor in her divorce action.Â  Defense counsel indicated he had had some negotiations with the solicitor concerning the charges against Gregory, and that Gregory was thereafter indicted for another charge (sexual exploitation of a minor).Â  Counsel advised Gregory of his representation of the assistant solicitor when it became apparent the case was going to trial.Â  
  The trial court inquired in what manner Gregory would be prejudiced by counselâ€™s continued representation.Â  Counselâ€™s response was that Gregoryâ€™s confidence in his ability was diminished, regardless of whether the solicitor was out of the case because Gregory believed they may have been â€œin cahoots.â€Â  The court then indicated that the assistant solicitor would not participate in the trial, and the case would be prosecuted by another solicitor.Â  The trial court ruled Gregory had not shown he was prejudiced, and that defense counsel had not done anything inappropriate.Â  Accordingly, the motions to be relieved and for a continuance were denied.Â Â Â  
  Gregory asserts the trial court erred in denying counselâ€™s motion to be relieved and in denying a continuance based upon counselâ€™s conflict of interest.Â  We agree.
  â€œ[A] motion to relieve counsel is addressed to the discretion of the trial judge and will not be disturbed absent an abuse of discretion.â€ State v. Graddick, 345 S.C. 383, 385, 548 S.E.2d 210, 211 (2001) (citation omitted).Â  An actual conflict of interest occurs where an attorney owes a duty to a party whose interests are adverse to the defendantâ€™s.Â  Fuller v. State, 347 S.C. 630, 557 S.E.2d 664 (2001).Â  The mere possibility defense counsel may have a conflict of interest is insufficient to impugn a criminal conviction. See Langford v. State, 310 S.C. 357, 359, 426 S.E.2d 793, 795 (1993) (citing Cuyler v. Sullivan, 446 U.S. 335, 350, 100 S.Ct. 1708, 64 L.Ed.2d 333 (1980).Â  However, a defendant need not demonstrate prejudice if there is an actual conflict of interest.Â  Thomas v. State, 346 S.C. 140, 551 S.E.2d 254 (2001); Duncan v. State, 281 S.C. 435, 315 S.E.2d 809 (1984) citing Cuyler v. Sullivan, 446 U.S. 335, 348-350, 100 S.Ct. 1708, 1718-19, 64 L.Ed.2d 333 (1980).Â  
  In Duncan v. State, 281 S.C. at 438, 315 S.E.2d at 811 (1984), this Court set forth the following test to determine when an actual conflict of interest occurs: 
  
  . . . when a defense attorney places himself in a situation inherently conducive to divided loyalties. . . .Â  If a defense attorney owes duties to a
  party whose interests are adverse to those of the defendant, then an actual conflict exists.Â  The interests of the other client and the defendant are sufficiently adverse if it is shown that the attorney owes a duty to the defendant to take some action that could be detrimental to his other client.Â  An actual conflict of interest occurs where an
  attorney owes a duty to a party whose interests are adverse to the defendant's.Â  
  
  citing Zuck v. State of Alabama, 588 F.2d 436, 439 (5th Cir.1979).Â  
  The question in this case is whether defense counsel owed duties to a party whose interests were adverse to Gregory.Â  Under this Courtâ€™s holding in Duncan and the case cited therein, Zuck v. Alabama, we find that he did.Â  In Zuck v. Alabama, the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals held that where the law firm retained to represent the defendant in a murder trial also represented the state prosecutor in an unrelated civil trial, there was an actual conflict of interest, and the conflict rendered the trial fundamentally unfair.Â  The court noted that â€œthe basis of these decisions is our belief that the sixth amendment requires that a defendant may not be represented by counsel who might be tempted to dampen the ardor of his defense in order to placate his other client. . . . This possibility is sufficient to constitute an actual conflict as a matter of law.â€ 588 F.2d at 440 (emphasis supplied).Â  Similarly, in People v. Castro, 657 P.2d 932 (Colo. 1983), the Supreme Court of Colorado held a defense attorneyâ€™s representation of the district attorney on criminal charges of overspending his office budget, while simultaneously representing the defendant on a criminal charge of murder, created a conflict of interest, notwithstanding the district attorney did not participate in the trial of the case.Â  The Castro court stated, â€œ[t]he District Attorneyâ€™s office, for example, in order to avoid any appearance of favoritism, might well take an unusually hard line on plea bargaining to the disadvantage of the defendant.Â  Defense counsel, in turn, might be reluctant to incur the disfavor of her other client, the district attorney, by pressing hard for the best possible plea bargain for the defendant. . . . What is critical, in our view, is the presence of a real and substantial conflict that placed the defense attorney in a situation inherently conducive to and productive of divided loyalties.â€Â  657 P.2d at 945.[1]Â Â  
  In this case, we find Gregoryâ€™s attorney had an actual conflict because he placed himself in a â€œsituation inherently conducive to divided loyaltiesâ€ by simultaneously representing Gregory and the assistant solicitor who was handling his criminal case.Â  Given the actual conflict, Gregory is not required to demonstrate prejudice.Â  Thomas, supra.Â  
  In light of our holding, we need not address the remaining issues raised by Gregory.Â  The judgment below is reversed and the matter remanded for a new trial.
   REVERSED AND REMANDED.
   TOAL, C.J., MOORE, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.



  [1]Â  The possibility that the ardor of counselâ€™s defense was dampened by his representation of the solicitor is apparent from the record.Â  Although Gregory raised numerous issues on appeal, the majority were not preserved for review because they were not objected to at trial.Â  Further, the fact that another charge was brought against Gregory subsequent to counselâ€™s negotiations with the solicitor lend credence to the suggestion that the solicitorâ€™s office may have taken an unusually hard line against Gregory, simply to avoid any appearance of favoritism.Â Â  Â

The Supreme Court of South Carolina

 Pursuant to Article V, § 4, of the South Carolina Constitution, we hereby amend Rule 404(c)(5), SCACR, regarding information required to be included in an application for admission pro hac vice, by deleting the word “other”. title: Gilchrist v. State
description: In this PCR case, the Court addresses allegations of ineffective assistance of appellate counsel regarding the self-defense charge.
text:
Gilchrist v. St


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Jimmy Gary Gilchrist, Petitioner,
v.
State of South Carolina,
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal from McCormick County
James R. Barber, III, Circuit Court Judge

ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Opinion No. 25973
Submitted March 16, 2005 - Filed April 25, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Petitioner Jimmy Gary Gilchrist, pro se.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Assistant Attorney General Elizabeth R. McMahon, all of Columbia, for respondent.
      
    
  


 JUSTICE MOORE:Â  Petitioner was indicted for murder and convicted of voluntary manslaughter for the fatal shooting of twenty-three-year-old Thomas Wideman.Â  Petitioner admitted shooting Wideman but claimed self-defense.Â  After his conviction was affirmed on appeal,[1] petitioner commenced this post-conviction relief (PCR) action.Â  The PCR court denied relief.Â  We granted a writ of certiorari to consider petitionerâ€™s allegations regarding ineffective assistance of appellate counsel.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
The shooting occurred inside a dance club in McCormick County after a verbal confrontation in the parking lot.Â  The Stateâ€™s witnesses testified Wideman was sitting in a parked vehicle talking with two of his sisters and a friend when petitioner approached and asked Wideman to move his car.Â  When Widemanâ€™s sister responded, petitioner called her â€œignorant.â€Â  Wideman and petitioner then exchanged angry words.Â  In the club, Wideman complained to his sister that petitioner was staring at him.Â  As last call was announced, petitioner walked toward Wideman and shot him.Â  When Wideman fell, petitioner shot him two more times.Â  Wideman died shortly thereafter.Â  
The State presented witnesses who testified they never saw Wideman with a gun on the night he was shot.Â  However, defense witness Leroy Brown testified he saw Wideman in the club with a gun stuck down inside his pants immediately before the shooting.Â  Derek Ridenhour testified that after the shooting, someone tried to hand him Widemanâ€™s gun for safekeeping but he refused to take it.Â  Petitioner also testified he saw a gun in Widemanâ€™s hand during their verbal confrontation in the parking lot.Â  
Petitioner further testified that before going back inside the club, he took his gun from his truck and put it in his pocket for â€œprotection.â€Â  In the club, petitioner and Wideman had another confrontation.Â  According to petitioner, Wideman continued staring at him across the room.Â  Wideman â€œpulled up his shirt and showed the gunâ€ while pointing at the door.Â  
When last call was announced, petitioner was concerned that â€œas soon as I went out that door [Wideman] could have did anything,â€ so petitioner approached Wideman to tell him â€œhe need to stop before somebody got hurt.â€Â  Wideman jumped up from his seat and was going for his gun when petitioner shot him.Â  Wideman was still reaching for his gun after he fell so petitioner continued shooting.
ISSUES

  
    
      
        1. 
         Was appellate counsel ineffective for failing to appeal the trial judgeâ€™s refusal to give an appearances charge?
      
      
        2.
         Was appellate counsel ineffective for failing to appeal the trial judgeâ€™s refusal to charge immunity from retreat?
      
    
  

DISCUSSION
1.Â  Appearances charge

At trial, counsel submitted a request to charge as follows:
DEFENDANTâ€™S PROPOSED INSTRUCTION NO. 2
The test is not whether there was testimony of an intended attack but whether or not the defendant believed he was in imminent danger of death or serious bodily harm, and he is not required to show that such danger actually existed because he had a right to act upon such appearances as would cause a reasonable and prudent man of ordinary firmness and courage to entertain the same belief.
AUTHORITY:
 State v. Jackson, 87 S.E.2d 681 (1955).

(emphasis added).
At the charge conference, the trial judge distributed his proposed charge which read:

The defendant must have actually believed he was in imminent danger of losing his life or sustaining serious bodily injury, or the defendant must have actually been in such imminent danger. . . . If the defense relates to a belief by a defendant that he was in such imminent danger, the circumstances must have been such that a reasonably prudent person of ordinary firmness and courage could have entertained the same belief.

The following colloquy then occurred between counsel and the bench:

MR. MIMS:Â  Your honor, I have Number Two, State versus Jackson, as the authority.
THE COURT:Â  All right.Â  Well. . . 
MR. BAGGETT:Â  I believe you had that covered on your point three on self-defense, your honor.
THE COURT:Â  Yes, sir, I think I had it covered.Â  When the Supreme Court went back through and considered Davis . . . there is this addition about if the defendant was actually in danger or whether he believed he was in danger and I think Iâ€™ve covered those things in my charge.

Counsel said nothing further and did not object when the charge was given. 
First, appellate counsel is not ineffective for failing to raise on appeal an issue that was not preserved for review.Â  Legge v. State, 349 S.C. 222, 562 S.E.2d 618 (2002).Â  We find trial counselâ€™s submission of the request to charge, without any further explanation of his point, was insufficient to preserve for review the trial courtâ€™s failure to charge the specific language regarding â€œa right to act on appearances.â€Â  
In State v. Johnson, 333 S.C. 62, 66, 508 S.E.2d 29, 31 (1998), we set out this preservation rule:Â  â€œ[W]here a party requests a jury charge and, after opportunity for discussion, the trial judge declines the charge, it is unnecessary to preserve the point on appeal, to renew the request at conclusion of the courtâ€™s instructions.â€Â  When given the opportunity, counsel must articulate a reason for the requested charge.Â  Counsel need not object to the charge when given if the basis of the requested charge is clear from the record.Â  It is not for the trial judge to study the requested charge and make an informed decision with no further input from counsel, especially in a situation such as this where there is only a subtle difference in the language of the judgeâ€™s proposed charge and the language of the request.[2]
In any event, aside from the lack of preservation, we find appellate counsel was not ineffective for failing to raise this issue.Â  A PCR applicant has the burden of proving appellate counsel's performance was deficient.Â  Anderson v. State, 354 S.C. 431, 581 S.E.2d 834 (2003); Southerland v. State, 337 S.C. 610, 524 S.E.2d 833 (1999).Â  Appellate counsel is not required to raise every nonfrivolous issue that is presented by the record.Â  Tisdale v. State, 357 S.C. 474, 594 S.E.2d 166 (2004).Â  
A defendant is entitled to an appearances charge where the claim of self-defense arises from a mistaken appearance of danger.Â  State v. Starnes, 340 S.C. 312, 531 S.E.2d 907 (2000).Â  Here, petitioner introduced evidence Wideman was actually armed with a gun at the time of the shooting and trial counsel focused extensively on the corroborative evidence in closing.Â  Counsel concluded his argument by stating:

Now, to think that [Wideman] didnâ€™t have a gun would really stretch the imagination and it would really make you wonder about doubt. . . . [Petitioner] said he had a gun, besides all these other people who independently testified and independently gave statements that they saw a gun on [Wideman] and I submit he did have a gun.

Petitionerâ€™s claim of self-defense did not rely on a mistaken appearance of danger.Â  The failure to give an appearances charge was therefore not reversible error and appellate counsel was not ineffective for failing to argue this issue on appeal.Â  Accordingly, the PCR judge properly found appellate counsel was not ineffective. 
2.Â  Duty to retreat
Trial counsel requested the following charge which the trial judge refused to give:

If a person is assaulted while in a club of which he is a member and without fault in bring[ing] on the difficulty, he is not bound to retreat in order to invoke the benefit of the doctrine of self-defense, but may stand his ground and repel the attack with as much force as is reasonably necessary.

Counselâ€™s request was based on this Courtâ€™s holding in State v. Marlowe, 120 S.C. 205, 112 S.E. 921 (1922), which involved a shooting at an Elkâ€™s Club.Â  The defendant was a member of the club and the victim was not.Â  The Court held it was error to refuse to charge that â€œthe law of retreat does not apply to a club member when attacked by another in the club roomsâ€ because â€œ[a] man is no more bound to allow himself to be run out of his rest room than his workshop.â€Â  112 S.E. at 922.Â  
Here, the â€œclubâ€ in which the shooting occurred was a â€œdance clubâ€ which charged $5 for admission.Â  There is no evidence petitioner was a â€œmemberâ€ of this club.Â  Accordingly, the trial judge did not err in refusing the charge and appellate counsel was not ineffective for failing to raise the issue on appeal.
In any event, we take this opportunity to overrule the analysis in State v. Marlowe elevating a â€œclubâ€ to the possessory status of a home or place of business.Â  This expansion of the immunity-from-retreat doctrine is not good public policy, especially in the contemporary context of â€œprivate clubs.â€ 
CONCLUSION
We affirm petitionerâ€™s remaining issues pursuant to Rule 220(b), SCACR, and the following authority:Â  Issue 1:Â  Legge v. State, 349 S.C. 222, 562 S.E.2d 618 (2002) (appellate counsel not ineffective for failing to raise an issue where no objection was preserved at trial); State v. Addison, 343 S.C. 290, 540 S.E.2d 449 (2000) (charge regarding Stateâ€™s burden to disprove self-defense should be given if requested but only for cases tried after the filing of this Courtâ€™s opinion in State v. Wiggins, 330 S.C. 538, 500 S.E.2d 489 (1998)); Issues 3 & 4:Â  State v. Burton, 302 S.C. 494, 397 S.E.2d 90 (1990) (no error where charge given adequately covered substance of requested charge).Â  The PCR courtâ€™s denial of relief is
AFFIRMED.
TOAL, C.J., WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1]State v. Gilchrist, 342 S.C. 369, 536 S.E.2d 868 (2000).
[2]In fact, in two early cases, we held a charge regarding the defendantâ€™s belief he was in danger, similar to the charge given here, covered the substance of an appearances charge.Â  State v. McGee, 185 S.C. 184, 193 S.E. 303 (1937); State v. Scruggs, 94 S.C. 304, 77 S.E. 944 (1913).Â  In recent cases, however, we have found such a charge does not cover an appearances charge.Â  Eg., State v. Starnes, 340 S.C. 312, 531 S.E.2d 907 (2000); Battle v. State, 305 S.C. 460, 409 S.E.2d 400 (1991); Â State v. Fuller, 297 S.C. 440, 377 S.E.2d 328 (1989).

title: Guffey v. Columbia/Colleton Regional Hospital
description: This case involves issues of proximate cause and the exclusion of evidence in the context of medical malpractice.
text:
Guffey v. Columbia/Colleton


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Brenda A. Guffey, Personal Representative of the Estate of James Fred
Guffey, Appellant,
v.
Columbia/Colleton Regional Hospital, Inc., W.W. King, M.D., and David E.
Meacher, M.D., P.A., Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal from Colleton County
Perry M. Buckner, III, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 25974
Heard November 18, 2004 - Filed April 25, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
John E. Parker and Bert G. Utsey, III, both of Peters, Murdaugh, Parker, Eltzroth & Detrick, P.A., of Walterboro, for appellant.
C. Mitchell Brown, Zoe Sanders Nettles, and Elizabeth Herlong Campbell, all of Nelson Mullins Riley & Scarborough, of Columbia, for respondent Columbia/Colleton Regional Hospital, Inc.
Stephen L. Brown, John Hamilton Smith, and D. Jay Davis, Jr., of Young, Clement, Rivers & Tisdale, of Charleston, for respondents W.W. King, M.D. and David E. Meacher, M.D., P.A.
      
    
  


 ACTING CHIEF JUSTICE MOORE:Â  Appellant commenced this wrongful death action as personal representative of her husbandâ€™s estate alleging medical malpractice.Â  She appeals a directed verdict and the exclusion of evidence.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
James Guffey (Decedent) suffered cardiac arrest at age fifty on September 3, 1997, twenty-five hours after he was discharged from the emergency room at respondent Columbia/Colleton Regional Hospital (Hospital).Â  Decedent had previously undergone two angioplasty surgeries in 1995 to treat unstable angina and subsequently was on medication, including nitroglycerin as needed for pain.Â  He had a check-up every month with his cardiologist, Dr. Reeves.
Two years after his surgeries, on September 2, 1997, Decedent came home early from work complaining of a headache and indigestion.Â  During the course of the evening, Decedent took three doses of nitroglycerin.Â  Finally, at about 11:00 p.m., Decedent said he needed to go to the hospital because he â€œfelt like he did the last time,â€ referring to his 1995 cardiac episode.Â  At Hospitalâ€™s emergency room, Decedent was treated with nitroglycerin paste and discharged by Dr. William King.[1]Â  
Decedent stayed in bed the next day still complaining of headache and indigestion.Â  During the night, he suffered cardiac arrest.Â  He was brain-dead by the time he arrived at the hospital and died several days later.
Dr. King testified he had attempted to contact Decedentâ€™s cardiologist, Dr. Reeves, while Decedent was at the emergency room.Â  The call was answered by Dr. Reevesâ€™s associate, Dr. Grayson.Â  Dr. Grayson told Dr. King that it was reasonable to send Decedent home but to have him see Dr. Reeves in the morning.Â  Dr. King told Decedent to return to the emergency room if he had pain during the night and if he had no pain, he should call Dr. Reevesâ€™s office in the morning for an appointment.Â  Decedent did not seek further medical care before suffering cardiac arrest the next night.
Appellantâ€™s medical expert, Dr. Wood, testified that Decedentâ€™s symptoms indicated he had unstable, as opposed to stable angina, and therefore he should not have been discharged from the emergency room.[2]Â  Dr. Wood testified that the pain caused by stable angina is relieved with nitroglycerin whereas the pain from unstable angina is not.Â  Decedentâ€™s history taken at the emergency room indicated he had â€œrelief of the chest pain but still had tightness in his chest.â€Â  From this history, Dr. Wood concluded Decedent was suffering unstable angina.Â  It was his opinion that Dr. King deviated from the standard of care in not admitting Decedent to the hospital.Â  
Hospitalâ€™s medical experts, on the other hand, testified Decedentâ€™s symptoms indicated he had stable angina because he did have pain relief from the nitroglycerin with only â€œresidual tightness.â€Â  
The jury returned a verdict for Hospital on the issue of Dr. Kingâ€™s negligence in failing to admit Decedent to the hospital.
ISSUES

  
    
      
        1.
         Did the trial court err in granting a directed verdict regarding conflicting discharge instructions?
      
      
        2. 
         Did the trial court err in excluding evidence of conflicting discharge instructions?
      
    
  

DISCUSSION
1.Â  Directed verdict
Appellant accompanied Decedent to the emergency room.Â  On cross-examination, she denied Decedent was told at the time of his discharge to contact his cardiologist, Dr. Reeves, in the morning.Â  On re-direct, counsel referred to a document entitled â€œAftercare Instructionsâ€ which Decedent was given by Hospitalâ€™s staff when he was discharged.Â  The document states:Â  â€œTHESE ARE YOUR FOLLOW-UP INSTRUCTIONS!Â  Call Dr. Hiott [Decedentâ€™s family doctor] in 2 days if not much better.Â  Call sooner if worsening.â€Â  This document was admitted into evidence.
At the close of appellantâ€™s case, Hospital moved for a directed verdict on the allegation that Hospital was negligent in giving these aftercare instructions which conflicted with Dr. Kingâ€™s instructions to contact the cardiologist in the morning.Â  The trial judge found appellant had presented no evidence the discrepancy in instructions was the proximate cause of Decedentâ€™s death and granted the motion.[3]
A directed verdict should be granted where the evidence raises no issue for the jury as to the defendant's liability.Â  Roberts v. Hunter, 310 S.C. 364, 426 S.E.2d 797 (1993).Â  On review, we will affirm a directed verdict where there is no evidence on any one element of the alleged cause of action.Â  First State Savings and Loan v. Phelps, 299 S.C. 441, 385 S.E.2d 821 (1989).Â Â  In a medical malpractice action, the plaintiff must establish proximate cause as well as the negligence of the physician.Â  Ellis v. Oliver, 323 S.C. 121, 473 S.E.2d 793 (1996).Â Â  
There is no evidence Decedent relied on Hospitalâ€™s aftercare instructions and for this reason did not call his cardiologist.Â  Further, the record contains no expert testimony Decedentâ€™s death could have been prevented had he seen his cardiologist the next morning.Â  See Bramlette v. Charter-Medical-Columbia, 302 S.C. 68, 393 S.E.2d 914 (1990) (expert testimony is required to establish proximate cause in a medical malpractice case if outside the common knowledge or experience of laypersons); Green v. Lilliewood, 272 S.C. 186, 249 S.E.2d 910 (1978) (medical malpractice plaintiff relying on expert testimony must introduce evidence that defendant's negligence most probably resulted in the injuries alleged).Â  Because there is no evidence the conflicting discharge instructions proximately caused Decedentâ€™s death, the trial judge properly granted a directed verdict on this allegation of negligence.
2.Â  Exclusion of evidence
Hospital moved to strike the â€œAftercare Instructions,â€ along with evidence of Hospitalâ€™s internal policies regarding discharge instructions, after withdrawing comparative negligence as a defense.Â  In light of counselâ€™s assurance comparative negligence would not be argued to the jury, the trial judge found the contested evidence irrelevant and granted the motion to strike.[4]Â  
We find no error.Â  When the directed verdict on the issue of Hospitalâ€™s negligence for conflicting instructions was properly granted, this evidence became irrelevant.Â  Comparative negligence was not argued in closing nor submitted to the jury.Â  Because there was no issue of Decedentâ€™s negligence that might be explained by an inference he followed these instructions, there was no prejudice from the exclusion of this evidence. Â The exclusion of evidence that is not relevant to some matter in issue cannot be prejudicial.Â  See Otis Elevator, Inc. v. Hardin Const. Co. Group, Inc., 316 S.C. 292, 450 S.E.2d 41 (1994) (no error in the exclusion of evidence absent a showing of prejudice).Â  
CONCLUSION
Appellantâ€™s remaining issues are without merit and we affirm pursuant to Rule 220(b), SCACR.Â  See Issue 2:Â  Green v. Lilliewood, 272 S.C. 186, 249 S.E.2d 910 (1978) (medical malpractice plaintiff relying on expert testimony must introduce evidence that defendantâ€™s negligence most probably resulted in the injuries alleged); Issue 4:Â  Keaton ex rel. Foster v. Greenville Hosp. System, 334 S.C. 488, 514 S.E.2d 570 (1999) (jury charge correct if when read as whole, charge contains correct definition and adequately covers law); see also State v. Smith, 315 S.C. 547, 446 S.E.2d 411 (1994) (jury instructions should be considered as whole, and if as whole they are free from error, any isolated portions which may be misleading do not constitute reversible error).
AFFIRMED.
WALLER, J., and Acting Justices Reginald I. Lloyd and R. Markley Dennis, Jr., concur.Â  BURNETT, J., dissenting in a separate opinion.
JUSTICE BURNETT:Â  I respectfully dissent.Â  The trial court committed reversible error in granting a directed verdict on one of Appellantâ€™s central allegations of negligence and in excluding evidence related to that allegation.
This appeal offers a textbook example of an instance in which Appellant was erroneously prohibited from presenting crucial, admissible evidence and testimony to prove her case to the jury.Â  The prejudicial error, in my opinion, is clear and unambiguous, and Appellant is entitled to a new trial.

Appellant raises two related issues:
I.Â  Did the trial court err in granting a directed verdict against Appellant on the issue of whether Hospital was negligent in providing conflicting discharge instructions?
II.Â  Did the trial court err in striking from evidence two exhibits relating to discharge instructions provided by Hospital and prohibiting testimony about those instructions?

STANDARD OF REVIEW
In ruling on a motion for directed verdict, the trial court must view the evidence and the inferences which reasonably can be drawn therefrom in the light most favorable to the party opposing the motion.Â  The trial court must deny the motion when either the evidence yields more than one inference or its inference is in doubt.Â  Strange v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Highways & Pub. Transp., 314 S.C. 427, 429-30, 445 S.E.2d 439, 440 (1994).Â  If the evidence is susceptible of more than one reasonable inference, the case must be submitted to the jury.Â  Quesinberry v. Rouppasong, 331 S.C. 589, 594, 503 S.E.2d 717, 720 (1998).Â  When considering directed verdict motions, neither the trial court nor the appellate court has authority to decide credibility issues or resolve conflicts in the testimony or evidence.Â  Creech v. S.C. Wildlife and Marine Resources Dept., 328 S.C. 24, 491 S.E.2d 571 (1997).Â  In essence, the appellate court must determine whether a verdict for a party opposing the motion would be reasonably possible under the facts as liberally construed in his favor.Â  Harvey v. Strickland, 350 S.C. 303, 309, 566 S.E.2d 529, 532 ( 2002); Bultman v. Barber, 277 S.C. 5, 7, 281 S.E.2d 791, 792 (1981).
The admission or exclusion of evidence is within the sound discretion of the trial court and the trial courtâ€™s decision will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Pike v. S.C. Dept. of Transp., 343 S.C. 224, 234, 540 S.E.2d 87, 92 (2000); Gooding v. St. Francis Xavier Hosp., 326 S.C. 248, 252, 487 S.E.2d 596, 598 (1997). Â An abuse of discretion occurs when the ruling is based on an error of law or a factual conclusion without evidentiary support.Â  Carlyle v. Tuomey Hosp., 305 S.C. 187, 193, 407 S.E.2d 630, 633 (1991); Fontaine v. Peitz, 291 S.C. 536, 538, 354 S.E.2d 565, 566 (1987).Â  To warrant reversal based on the admission or exclusion of evidence, the appellant must prove both the error of the ruling and the resulting prejudice, i.e., there is a reasonable probability the juryâ€™s verdict was influenced by the challenged evidence or the lack thereof.Â  Hanahan v. Simpson, 326 S.C. 140, 156, 485 S.E.2d 903, 911 (1997); Timmons v. S.C. Tricentennial Commn., 254 S.C. 378, 405, 175 S.E.2d 805, 819 (1970); Powers v. Temple, 250 S.C. 149, 160, 156 S.E.2d 759, 764 (1967).
I.Â  DIRECTED VERDICT REGARDING CONFLICTING DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS
Appellant argues the trial court erred in granting a directed verdict on the issue of whether Hospital and its agent, King, were negligent in providing conflicting discharge instructions to Decedent.Â  I agree.
It is undisputed Decedent was given conflicting discharge instructions by King and Hospitalâ€™s staff.Â Â  King testified he verbally told Decedent to follow up with his cardiologist, Reeves, the next morning and he documented this instruction in emergency room records which were not provided to Decedent the night of his visit.Â  In contrast, the written discharge instructions Decedent received from Hospitalâ€™s staff, titled â€œAftercare Instructions,â€ stated:Â  â€œTHESE ARE YOUR FOLLOW-UP INSTRUCTIONS!Â  Call Dr. Hiott [Decedentâ€™s family doctor] in 2 days if not much better.Â  Call sooner if worsening.â€Â  On cross-examination, Appellant denied knowing Decedent was told at the time of his discharge from the emergency room to contact his cardiologist in the morning.
At the close of Appellantâ€™s case, Hospital moved for a directed verdict on the allegation Hospital was negligent in giving conflicting discharge instructions.Â  The trial judge granted the motion, ruling Appellant had not presented expert testimony the conflicting instructions were the proximate cause of Decedentâ€™s death.
This ruling constitutes reversible error.Â  Appellant produced no explicit expert testimony Decedentâ€™s death was proximately caused by the failure to see his cardiologist the next morning.Â  See e.g. Bramlette v. Charter-Medical-Columbia, 302 S.C. 68, 72, 393 S.E.2d 914, 916 (1990) (expert testimony is required to establish proximate cause in a medical malpractice case if outside the common knowledge or experience of laypersons); Gooding v. St. Francis Xavier Hosp., 326 S.C. 248, 254, 487 S.E.2d 596, 599 (1997) (â€œunless the subject is a matter of common knowledge, the plaintiff must use expert testimony to establish both the standard of care and the defendantâ€™s failure to conform to that standardâ€).Â  I disagree with the majorityâ€™s conclusion the record contains no expert testimony Decedentâ€™s death was proximately caused by the failure to see his cardiologist the next morning.Â  I also disagree with the majorityâ€™s conclusion the record contains no evidence Decedent relied on the conflicting aftercare instructions.
A plaintiff may present both expert testimony and circumstantial evidence of a physicianâ€™s culpability, and the inquiry need only be whether there is sufficient competent evidence from which the jury may infer a causal connection between the physicianâ€™s conduct and the injury.Â  Green v. Lilliewood, 272 S.C. 186, 189-93, 249 S.E.2d 910, 912-13 (1978) (reversing grant of directed verdict for defendant physician where plaintiff relied on both expert testimony and circumstantial evidence which showed plaintiffâ€™s medical problems began soon after insertion of intrauterine device); Shelnitz v. Greenberg, 509 A.2d 1023, 1027 (Conn. 1986) (causation in medical malpractice case may be proven both by expert testimony, which usually is necessary to establish the standard of care, and circumstantial evidence); 1 Dan B. Dobbs, The Law of Torts Â§ 173 (2001) (courts recognize juries must be permitted to make causal judgments from ordinary experience without demanding an impossible degree of proof and â€œ[e]ven scientific or medical causation might be proven by circumstantial evidence leading to an inference of causationâ€); Prosser & Keeton on the Law of Torts Â§ 41 (5th ed. 1984) (â€œCircumstantial evidence, expert testimony, or common knowledge may provide a basis from which the causal sequence may be inferred.â€).
Appellantâ€™s expert, Wood, testified that had Decedent been admitted to the hospital rather than discharged, he â€œmore than likely would have survived.â€Â  Wood testified â€œpeople have heart attacks and get hospitalized for it all the time, and, you know, these are general statistics, but probably ninety percent of people that get hospitalized with heart attacks live.â€Â  A reasonable inference which may be drawn from this testimony is if Decedent had seen his cardiologist the next morning as directed by King, he could have been admitted to the hospital where he most likely would have survived his heart attack.
The expertâ€™s testimony that the proximate cause of Decedentâ€™s death was the lack of hospitalization at the time of his cardiac arrest was sufficient to submit to the jury the issue of Hospitalâ€™s negligence, regardless of whether the lack of hospitalization occurred on the night of his visit to the emergency room or the morning after.Â  Therefore, liberally construing the evidence Decedent did not return to his cardiologist the next morning as directed by King, Hospital gave Decedent discharge instructions stating he should wait two days to see his family doctor, and expert testimony he most likely would have survived had he been hospitalized at the time of his heart attack, it is reasonably probable a verdict would have been rendered in Appellantâ€™s favor had the jury been allowed to consider negligence allegations relating to the conflicting discharge instructions.
In addition, the record contains circumstantial evidence Decedent relied on Hospitalâ€™s written discharge instruction (call family doctor â€œin 2 days if not much better.Â  Call sooner if worsening.â€) instead of Kingâ€™s verbal instruction (see cardiologist the next morning).Â  Appellant testified Decedent stated on September 3 he did not need to return to the hospital because, although King had told Decedent he would have a â€œterrible headacheâ€ from the nitroglycerin, he expected to â€œbe better in a day or two.â€Â  Thus Decedent told his wife he needed to give his condition a couple of days to improve - just like Hospital told him to do in its written discharge instructions.Â  See e.g. Mahaffey v. Ahl, 264 S.C. 241, 247, 214 S.E.2d 119, 122 (1975) (â€œit is axiomatic in this State that issues of negligence and proximate cause may be resolved by direct or circumstantial evidenceâ€).
In pointing to circumstantial evidence surrounding Decedentâ€™s actions, I do not suggest expert testimony is not usually required to prove medical malpractice.Â  I do conclude that expert testimony identifying the lack of hospitalization as a proximate cause of Decedentâ€™s death, combined with circumstantial evidence Decedent may have relied on discharge instructions in which he was not told to follow up promptly with a cardiologist who may have admitted him to the hospital before he suffered a fatal heart attack, are sufficient to create a jury question on whether Hospital and its admitted agent were negligent.Â  See Green, 272 S.C. at 189-93, 249 S.E.2d at 912-13; Shelnitz, 509 A.2d at 1027.
II.Â  EXCLUSION OF PLAINTIFFâ€™S EXHIBITS PERTAINING TO DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS
Appellant contends the trial court committed prejudicial error in striking from evidence two exhibits relating to discharge instructions provided by Hospital and prohibiting testimony about those instructions.Â  I agree.
The document titled â€œAftercare Instructions,â€ discussed above, was admitted in evidence by Appellant as Exhibit 18D.Â  This document instructed Decedent to call his family doctor if he was not feeling better in two days.Â  Appellant also offered Exhibit 22, which set forth Hospitalâ€™s policies regarding discharge instructions.Â  Based on its earlier, directed verdict ruling that Appellant had failed to present expert testimony the conflicting instructions proximately caused Decedentâ€™s death, the trial court prohibited Appellant from questioning Hospitalâ€™s witnesses about the exhibits or the conflicting discharge instructions. 
Hospital moved to strike Exhibits 18D and 22 after withdrawing its defense of comparative negligence before the case was submitted to the jury.Â  The trial court granted the motion, finding the exhibits were irrelevant because comparative negligence was no longer an issue.[5]
When evidence is erroneously excluded by the trial court, the appellate court usually engages in the following analysis to determine whether prejudice has occurred.Â  First, the appellate court considers, inter alia, whether the error may be deemed harmless because equivalent or cumulative evidence or testimony was offered; the aggrieved party still managed to accomplish his primary objective, such as eliciting testimony about an issue or effectively cross-examining a witness; the juryâ€™s verdict or a proper court ruling rendered the wrongly excluded evidence moot because it was relevant to an issue that did not have to be reached; the aggrieved party failed to establish a claim or defense even when both the admitted and excluded evidence are considered; or the wrongly excluded evidence involved a generally known fact.Â  Fields v. Regional Medical Center, Op. No. 25939 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed February 14, 2005) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 8 at 17, 27-29) (citing cases supporting each proposition).
Second, the appellate court considers whether, viewing a case as a whole, the wrongly excluded evidence or testimony was so crucial and important in proving the aggrieved partyâ€™s claim or defense that its exclusion constitutes prejudicial error, i.e., the aggrieved party demonstrates there is a reasonable probability the juryâ€™s verdict was influenced by the lack of the evidence.Â  Id. (citing cases).
The testimony of Appellantâ€™s medical expert that the proximate cause of Decedentâ€™s death was the lack of hospitalization at the time of his cardiac arrest was sufficient to submit to the jury the issue of Hospitalâ€™s negligence, regardless of whether the lack of hospitalization occurred on the night of his visit to the emergency room or the morning after.Â  Exhibit 18D was relevant and admissible because it contained the conflicting discharge instructions given to Decedent.Â  See Rules 401 and 402, SCRE (relevant evidence generally is admissible).Â  
Violation of a rule or regulation designed primarily for the safety of hospital patients will constitute negligence if the violation proximately results in the injury.Â  Steeves v. U.S., 294 F. Supp. 446, 455 (D.S.C. 1968).Â  Furthermore, relevant rules of a defendant hospital or company are admissible in evidence in a personal injury action regardless of whether rules were intended primarily for employee guidance, public safety, or both, because violation of such rules may constitute evidence of a breach of the duty of care and the proximate cause of injury.Â  Tidwell v. Columbia Ry., Gas & Elec. Co., 109 S.C. 34, 95 S.E. 109 (1918); see also Caldwell v. K-Mart Corp., 306 S.C. 27, 31-32, 410 S.E.2d 21, 24 (Ct. App. 1991) (when defendant adopts internal policies or self-imposed rules and thereafter violates those policies or rules, jury may consider such violations as evidence of negligence if they proximately caused a plaintiffâ€™s damages).Â  Thus, Exhibit 22, which listed Hospitalâ€™s policies and procedures on discharge instructions, was relevant and admissible to establish and define the standard of care Hospital was required to meet with regard to discharge instructions.Â  
King testified he was â€œstunnedâ€ and â€œvery much surprised that [Decedent] had not seen his cardiologist the next day because I thought he was quite clear what he was to do.â€Â  In light of expert testimony that Kingâ€™s instruction to see a cardiologist in the morning was appropriate, the implication that may be drawn from evidence heard by the jury is Decedent did not follow sound medical advice and, therefore, King should not be held responsible.Â  In fact, Hospitalâ€™s counsel argued in closing that Decedent knew from his cardiologist,Â  Reeves, he needed to seek immediate medical attention if his pain was not relieved with nitroglycerin, yet he did not return to the hospital the following day.Â  If the exhibits and testimony about the conflicting discharge instructions had been allowed, Appellant could have argued the instructions contained in Exhibit 18D were circumstantial evidence which explained Decedentâ€™s failure to follow Kingâ€™s directions, as well as evidence of the negligence of Hospital and its agent.Â  
In effect, Hospital gained an improper tactical advantage by withdrawing the issue of comparative negligence as a ground to exclude the conflicting discharge instructions - which left only the evidence that Decedent did not follow his doctorâ€™s orders.Â  Hospital then implicitly asserted the defense of comparative negligence in closing arguments despite agreeing to abandon that defense. 
Appellant did not present any equivalent or cumulative evidence about the conflicting discharge instructions; nor was Appellant able to accomplish her primary objective of demonstrating Hospitalâ€™s alleged negligence on this ground through other testimony or evidence.Â  Viewing the case as a whole, I conclude the wrongly excluded evidence and testimony was so crucial and important in proving Appellantâ€™s claim that its exclusion constitutes prejudicial error, i.e., Appellant has demonstrated there is a reasonable probability the juryâ€™s verdict was influenced by the lack of the evidence.
I would reverse the juryâ€™s verdict and remand this matter for a new trial.Â  The trial court committed reversible error in granting a directed verdict against Appellant on the issue of whether Hospital was negligent in providing conflicting discharge instructions.Â  The trial court also committed reversible error in striking from evidence two exhibits relating to discharge instructions provided by Hospital and prohibiting testimony about the conflicting instructions.[6]  

[1]Dr. King was named as a defendant.Â  The parties agreed before trial that the action would proceed solely against Hospital because Dr. King was acting as Hospitalâ€™s agent.Â  See Simmons v. Tuomey Reg. Med. Center, 341 S.C. 32, 533 S.E.2d 312 (2000) (hospitalâ€™s liability for acts of doctor-agent).
[2]According to medical testimony in the record, stable angina occurs when the coronary arteries become occluded over time and smaller arteries take over to aid in carrying blood to the heart muscle.Â  In this instance, the patient feels pain only on exertion because the smaller arteries cannot handle the extra need for blood.Â  The pain of stable angina improves with rest or with nitroglycerin.Â  Unstable angina, on the other hand, occurs when an artery is suddenly occluded by a blood clot.Â  The patient feels pain, or more frequent pain, even when resting.Â  The pain is not relieved with nitroglycerin.Â  A patient with unstable angina should be admitted to the hospital to prevent the clot from getting bigger.Â  If the blockage becomes too large, the patient will suffer a heart attack. 
[3]Appellant makes a procedural argument that the trial judge should not direct a verdict on one specification of negligence if any other specification is supported by the evidence.Â  The cases appellant cites do not stand for this proposition and we find it without merit.Â  Cf. Young v. Charleston & W.C. Ry. Co., 229 S.C. 580, 93 S.E.2d 866 (1956) (where defendant moved for directed verdict to keep entire case from being submitted to jury, motion properly denied because evidence supported at least one specification of negligence).Â Â  
[4]Further, the trial judge refused appellantâ€™s counter-motion that the discharge sheet with Dr. Kingâ€™s instructions also be struck.Â  Dr. Kingâ€™s discharge instructions remained relevant since they indicated his treatment conformed to the standard of care.Â  
[5]Â  Further, the trial judge refused Appellantâ€™s counter-motion that the discharge sheet containing Kingâ€™s instructions also be struck if Exhibit 18D were struck.Â  This ruling was correct.Â  Kingâ€™s discharge instructions remained relevant because they indicated his treatment conformed to the required standard of care as established by his expert witnessesâ€™ testimony.Â  The error was in not admitting the conflicting discharge instructions contained in Exhibit 18D, which constituted proof that Hospital and Kingâ€™s treatment did not conform to the required standard of care.
[6]Â  I agree with the majority the trial court did not err in granting a directed verdict on Appellantâ€™s claim Hospital was negligent due to Kingâ€™s failure to obtain and record an adequate medical history (Appellantâ€™s Issue 2).Â  Appellantâ€™s own medical expert, Wood, testified the history taken was adequate to conclude Decedent was suffering from unstable angina.Â  The record contains no evidence the failure to obtain an adequate history caused a misdiagnosis of stable angina and most probably caused Decedentâ€™s death.
I also agree with the majority the trial court did not err in its jury instructions establishing a presumption Hospital met the standard of care (Appellantâ€™s Issue 4).Â  When read as a whole, the charge properly informed the jury of the plaintiffâ€™s burden of proof and did not establish an erroneous presumption.Â  See Keaton ex rel. Foster v. Greenville Hosp. System, 334 S.C. 488, 514 S.E.2d 570 (1999) (jury charge is correct if, when read as whole, it correctly defines and adequately covers the law).

description: This is a death penalty case. The issues before the Court are whether (1) the trial court erred in refusing to grant a mistrial for the solicitor's argument to the jury, (2) whether the trial court erred in not charging the mitigating circumstances related to intoxication, and (3) did the trial judge err in sentencing Appellant for kidnapping?

Angleâ€œAngelâ€Joe Perrie Vazquez (Appellant) was convicted of two counts of murder, one count of armed robbery, four counts of


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Angle Vazquez, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal from Horry County
Â Paula H. Thomas, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 25975
Heard March 3, 2005 - Filed April 25, 2005

 AFFIRMED
IN PART; VACATED IN PART


  
    
      
Acting Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz, III, of the South Carolina Office of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, Assistant Attorney General Jeffrey A. Jacobs, all of Columbia; and John Gregory Hembree, of Conway, for Respondent.
      
    
  


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  Angle â€œAngelâ€ Joe Perrie Vazquez (Appellant) was convicted of two counts of murder, one count of armed robbery, four counts of kidnapping, and one count of criminal conspiracy.Â  Appellant was sentenced to death for the murders and thirty years for each count of kidnapping.Â  Appellant appealed.
Factual / Procedural Background
The events leading up to Appellantâ€™s arrest began at the Burger King restaurant (the restaurant) in Myrtle Beach where Appellant worked.Â  One of the restaurantâ€™s patrons overheard Appellant using profanity in the restaurant.Â  Appellant cursed at fellow employee Reginald Atkins for trying to feed a patronâ€™s dog french fries.Â  The patron, who was with her children, was offended by Appellantâ€™s language and phoned the restaurantâ€™s district manager from her cell phone while outside the restaurant.Â  The district manager returned the call immediately.Â  Once the patron told the district manager what happened, the district manager asked to speak to the store manager, Joey Williams.Â  As a result of the conversation with the district manager, Williams immediately fired Appellant and refunded the patronâ€™s money.Â  Employee Robbie Robertson was called in to complete Appellantâ€™s shift.Â  In addition, Kuma Walker was on duty at the restaurant at that time.Â  
Appellant called Shanira Robinson (girlfriend), with whom he shared a house, to tell her that he had been fired.Â  Around 5 p.m. Kevin Cochran drove Appellant home to Conway.Â  At some point during the drive, Appellant phoned his cousin, Michael Keith Howard.[1]Â  Howard met Appellant at Appellantâ€™s home.Â  While inside, Appellant removed a black case from a shelf in the closet.Â  Appellant told his girlfriend that he was going to Lake City and would return later.
However, Appellant and Howard did not go to Lake City.Â  After leaving the house, Appellant and Howard were seen at about 8 p.m. by the bartender at the Nuttinâ€™ Butt Horseplay strip club in Myrtle Beach, which is located near the Burger King restaurant where Appellant worked.
Later that evening, Appellant and Howard knocked on the back door of the Burger King restaurant.Â  Atkins and Williams opened the door, but asked them to go around front.Â  Appellant and Howard were seen by Nathan Danner, a patron of the restaurant, inside the restaurant.Â  Appellant was seen arguing with Williams.
While Atkins and Robertson were preparing to close the restaurant,[2] Appellant pulled out a gun and told Atkins and Robertson to get into the restaurantâ€™s freezer.Â  Appellant then locked the two in the freezer.Â  After about five minutes, Atkins and Robertson forced their way out of the freezer and fled through the back door.
Atkins and Robertson flagged down a former high school classmate, Ricky Galliard, and asked for a ride to Conway.Â  Galliard took Atkins and Robertson to Atkinsâ€™ home.Â  Atkins then called his mother and told her about the armed gunman at the restaurant.Â  At that point in time Atkins thought that his coworkers were just holding up the restaurant.Â  Atkins and his mother went back to the restaurant to see if Williams and Walker were alright.
Upon arriving at the restaurant, Atkins discovered that Williams and Walker had been shot and killed.Â  The police arrived, and Atkins told the police that a masked gunman robbed the restaurant.Â  Atkins did not initially indicate he knew the robbers.Â  Atkins was already on probation for gun charges and did not implicate Appellant that night because he did not want the police to suspect that he had any connection with the events that took place at the restaurant.
When investigating the scene, the police discovered that $837 had been stolen from the restaurant.Â  The police also discovered nine-millimeter shell casings and live nine-millimeter ammunition.Â  The crime scene investigator testified the shootings were done â€œexecutionâ€ style.
Appellant and Howard were seen at the Nuttinâ€™ Butt Horseplay strip club again between 9 p.m. and 10 p.m., after having left the club for about an hour.Â  Appellantâ€™s girlfriend testified that Appellant returned home between 10 p.m. and 11 p.m. to replace the case on the shelf in the closet.Â  Appellant then left.
At approximately 2 a.m. the next morning, a police officer saw Howard and Appellant run a stop sign in Lake City.Â  The officer attempted to pull them over.Â  Howard, who was driving, would not stop. Howard jumped from the car while it was still moving.Â  While attempting to drive the car from the passenger seat, Appellant ran the car into a mobile home.Â  When Appellant was arrested, he had $322.65 in his possession.Â  While in custody, Appellant called his girlfriend to ask her to get rid of his clothes and asked if she found the money he left in her purse.
The day after the killings, Atkins and Robertson admitted to the police they actually saw Appellant and Howard rob the restaurant.Â  This prompted the police to search Appellantâ€™s home.Â  At his home, the police discovered a nine-millimeter round on the shelf in the bedroom closet.Â  Later another box of nine-millimeter ammunition was found.
Further, the investigation led police to Kevin Cochran, who owned the case that Appellant stored in his closet.Â  At some point before the police searched the house, Cochran came back to Appellantâ€™s house and retrieved the case, which contained a nine-millimeter semi-automatic pistol.Â  Cochran gave the case to the police once he learned the weapon might have been used in the killings.
Ballistic analysis revealed that the bullets that killed Williams and Walker were fired from the nine-millimeter Cochran gave to the police.Â  In addition, the ammunition in Appellantâ€™s closet was the same as the ammunition and shell casings at the crime scene.Â  
After a jury trial, Appellant was convicted on all counts in the indictment.Â  Appellant was sentenced to death, thirty years for each count of kidnapping, thirty years for armed robbery, and five years for conspiracy.Â  This appeal followed and Appellant now raises the following issues for review:

  
    
      
        I.
